div1.head: Introduction
div1.p: This document presents the encoding specifications for the sources published by the VISUAL CONTAGIONS project. Among these sources, some of the exhibition catalogs, will expand BasArt, the database of an older project, Artl@s.

The aim of the VISUAL CONTAGIONS project is to study the global circulation of images from the 1890s to the advent of the Internet. It involves an innovative research on a corpus of images that need to be recovered, described, dated and georeferenced. Then, they will be analysed with the help of artificial vision algorithms, in order to identify the most reproduced images and the patterns that circulated the more between 1890 and 1990.

To visualize the circulation of images, VISUAL CONTAGIONS deploys a global IIIF database of images. This portal will group scanned images (which will be stored on UNIGE servers) and external images (accessible through their IIIF manifests). The encoded metadata will mainly be used for the generation of manifests, but it will also, in the case of the exhibition catalogs, expand BasArt.
As for Artl@s, it manages several research projects on artistic and cultural globalization. It also takes an active interest in digital methodologies and in the circulation of images.

One of its projects is BasArt, an online database of exhibition catalogs from the 19th and 20th centuries. To expand the database, Béatrice Joyeux-Prunel decided to find a way to process and structure the scanned exhibition catalogs in order to easily complete the database. They decided to use a pivot XML-TEI format and GROBID-dictionaries (a machine-learning software designed to automatically structure the lexicographical resources and to automatically encode the exhibition catalogs).

div2.head: Corpus
div2.p: The main corpus of VISUAL CONTAGIONS is made up of five types of printed and illustrated sources: exhibition catalogs, sales catalogs, periodicals, political and advertising posters and chapbooks. But these encoding specifications concern only two types of sources: the exhibition catalogs and the periodicals. The other sources will be integrated into the project in the future.

div2.head: The encoding structure
div2.p: The encoding structure is composed of a teiHeader and a body. These two parts are derived from two different steps of the project. The information relating to the header concerns both periodicals and exhibition catalogs, while the information relating to the body concerns only exhibition catalogs.

The header is automatically generated, using an XSLT stylesheet, from a CSV listing the periodicals and exhibition catalogs accessible online. But some information will need to be added directly to the TEI file. This header has been thought out to be multipurpose. Here is its general structure:

The catalog's body is derived from the GROBID-dictionaries output. However, the encoded output does not correspond to our encoding for exhibition catalogs, so we must transform some tags thanks to a XSLT stylesheet. Then we get an encoded catalog based on the five levels of GROBID-dictionaries which are the following ones:

In order to refine the encoding, we decided to add tags to specify biographical and descriptive information about the exhibited work that could be added in a second time, by hand or thanks to a script.
Concerning the periodicals, we decided to leave an empty body for the moment, because we only want to encode metadata.

div2.head: The TEI Header structure (teiHeader)
div2.p: This teiHeader was built to fulfill several objectives related to the VISUAL CONTAGIONS project. It had to contain the necessary information to generate IIIF manifests and also the necessary information for BasArt, the database of the Artl@s project (some exhibition catalogs will expand the database). Moreover, this teiHeader had to be adapted to encode the different types of sources chosen for the project (exhibition catalogs and periodicals for the moment).
This teiHeader is composed of three main sections:

div3.head: The File Description (fileDesc)
div3.p: The fileDesc constitutes the main part of this teiHeader. It contains the bibliographic description of the electronic version of the exhibition catalog or periodical. It gives information about the present document as well as about its source (paper and digitised version).

div4.head: The Title Statement (titleStmt)
div4.p: The titleStmt is the first of the three mandatory elements of the fileDesc. It contains the title of the electronic version of the document (exhibition catalog or periodical, for now) and the name of the person(s) in charge of its content.

titleStmt.title: La Chine à l'Exposition internationale des arts décoratifs et industriels modernes à Paris. Catalogue des œuvres d'art décoratif artistique et industrielles modernes exposées dans la section chinoise.

div4.p: We have decided to name the electronic version of the document in the same way as the original version, for the sake of clarity and in order to make the work on the TEI file easier for the team. The file naming (used by the system) appears, as for it, as an attribute of the TEI element, in the following way:

The editor element which has a role="metadata" attribute contains the name of the person who collected the metadata of the document. On the other hand, the element which has a role="data" attribute mentions the person who encoded the part of the TEI document contained in the text element.

div4.head: The Publication Statement (publicationStmt)
div4.p: The publicationStmt is the second mandatory element of the fileDesc. It groups informations about the publication of the electronic version of the document.

The publisher element provides details about the organisation responsible for the publication of the text. At this place, there are the project name, its director and the organisation name and address which it is attached to.
The publication date as well as the license information are also indicated in the publicationStmt.

div4.head: The Source Description (sourceDesc)
div4.p: The sourceDesc contains the description of the source of the electronic document, and for the exhibition catalogs, it contains information about the event associated with the source. It contains two main sections:

div5.head: The Bibliographic Citation (bibl)
div5.p: The bibl contains the bibliographic description of the physical document.

egXML.title: La Chine à l'Exposition internationale des arts décoratifs et industriels modernes à Paris. Catalogue des œuvres d'art décoratif artistique et industrielles modernes exposées dans la section chinoise.

div5.p: It also specifies its physical description.
A type attribute placed on the bibl element indicates the type of the document.
We decided to use a relatedItem element, to differentiate the physical location of the document (repository) and the information about its digital version (URL and author of the digitisation).

div5.head: The List of Events (listEvent)
div5.p: The exhibition is described within an event tag, itself contained in a listEvent tag. The type of event, as well as if the exhibition is a travelling one or not and the dates of the event are indicated in attributes placed on the event element. These pieces of information are necessary for the BasArt database (Artl@s project).

Then there are two head elements. In the first one, we indicate the title of the exhibition and the second one, concerns the exhibition group title (when it exists). A type attribute placed on the second head specifies the type of the exhibition.

egXML.head: La Chine à l'exposition internationale des arts décoratifs et industriels modernes à Paris

div5.p: The addresses list of the exhibition is specified in a desc element. We separated the address indicated in the printout and its standardized version in choiceorigregchoice elements. In some cases, there may be more than one address per section.

div3.head: The Profile Description (profileDesc)
div3.p: This profileDesc specifies the language of the text. The ISO 639-1 standard is used and mentioned in the ident attribute of the language element.

div3.head: The Encoding Description (encodingDesc)
div3.p:
The encodingDesc specifies the applications we used in our workflow to encode catalogs. It has two elements:
The samplingDecl (with a child element p) indicates the choice we made to process only the parts of the catalogs that are lists of entries. This precision is added automatically thanks to the XSLT stylesheet.
The appInfo (with a child element application) specifies the applications we used in our worflow. We automatically added information concerning Transkribus and GROBID-dictionaries thanks to the XSLT stylesheet.

samplingDecl.p: This electronic version of the catalog only reproduces the entries that correspond to exhibited works. All the text preceding or succeeding the list of documents is not reproduced below.

application.label: GROBID_Dictionaries - A machine learning software for structuring digitized dictionaries

div3.head: The Revision Description (revisionDesc)
div3.p: In this tag are indicated the modifications made to the file, as well as their author.

div2.head: The Text Structure of exhibition catalogs (text)
div2.p: The body of exhibition catalogs is composed of several entry recording exhibited works and some information about the exhibitor.

Sometimes, entries can be grouped by list, which indicate the name of a section such as the location of the work in the exhibition (gallery 1, red wing…), or artistic forms (paintings, sculpture, architecture…). We have to encode lists by hand because GROBID-dictionaries is not able to do it.

div3.head: The num section (num)
div3.p: The num is an optional tag to encode the number of the entry when it is not attached to the work but to the entry in general. It is the case in some catalogs which present lots or stands.

div3.head: The desc section (desc)
div3.p:
The desc gives information about the exhibitor. It can have two child elements:
The mandatory element name indicates the name of the exhibitor. It has a role="exhibitor" attribute to specify the role of the person or organisation named in the entry. In a second time, we could refine the encoding by adding surname and forename tags.
The non-mandatory element trait (with a child element p) indicates biographical information about the exhibitor. In a second time, we could refined the encoding by adding birth, occupation, residence, education, death, affiliation, nationality and/or event tags.

trait.p: Né à Rouen. Médaille de bronze, Caen, 1873. Rue Eau-de-Robec, 36, Rouen

div3.head: The item section (item)
div3.p:
The item gives information about the exhibited work. An entry could contain several items. Each item has a n attribute referring to the num element. It can have three child elements:
The non-mandatory element num indicates the number of the work.
The non-mandatory element title indicates the title of the work.
The non-mandatory element desc indicates descriptive information about the work. In a second time, we could refine the encoding by adding material, dimensions, date, history, org (place), measure (price), event, note, quote and/or signatures tags.

div3.head: The note section (note)
div3.p: The note is an optional tag to encode general notes about the entry.

trait.p: Né à Rouen. Médaille de bronze, Caen, 1873. Rue Eau-de-Robec, 36, Rouen.

item.title: La porte du Bac à Rouen

entry.note: (Voir à la Gravure et à l'Architecture.)

div2.head: The Text Structure of periodicals (text)
div2.p: The body of periodicals is not encoded, it only contains an empty p tag to validate the XML-TEI structure.
